byline.contributor: Hiroko Tabuchi contributed reporting from New York.

abstract: Supreme Court hears argument exploring religious sterotypes, employment discrimination and symbolism of Muslim head scarf, issuing from 2008 incident at Abercrombie & Fitch clothing store in Tulsa, Okla; Samantha Elauf was not hired by store because of her scarf, and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued on her behalf.
lead_paragraph: A vigorous argument before the Supreme Court explored religious stereotypes, employment discrimination and the symbolism of the Muslim head scarf, all arising from an encounter at a clothing store in Tulsa, Okla.

headline.main: In a Case of Religious Dress, Justices Explore the Obligations of Employers
headline.print_headline: In a Case of Religious Dress, Justices Explore the Obligations of Employers

snippet: A vigorous argument before the Supreme Court explored religious stereotypes, employment discrimination and the symbolism of the Muslim head scarf, all arising from an encounter at a clothing store in Tulsa, Okla.
